gh 1.1.0.9000
  • Reference
  • Articles
    • Managing Personal Access Tokens
  • Changelog

Query the GitHub API

Source: R/gh.R
gh.Rd

This is an extremely minimal client. You need to know the API to be able to use this client. All this function does is:

  • Try to substitute each listed parameter into endpoint, using the :parameter notation.

  • If a GET request (the default), then add all other listed parameters as query parameters.

  • If not a GET request, then send the other parameters in the request body, as JSON.

  • Convert the response to an R list using jsonlite::fromJSON().

gh(
  endpoint,
  ...,
  per_page = NULL,
  .token = NULL,
  .destfile = NULL,
  .overwrite = FALSE,
  .api_url = NULL,
  .method = "GET",
  .limit = NULL,
  .accept = "application/vnd.github.v3+json",
  .send_headers = NULL,
  .progress = TRUE
)

Arguments

endpoint

GitHub API endpoint. Must be one of the following forms:

  • METHOD path, e.g. GET /rate_limit,

  • path, e.g. /rate_limit,

  • METHOD url, e.g. GET https://api.github.com/rate_limit,

  • url, e.g. https://api.github.com/rate_limit.

If the method is not supplied, will use .method, which defaults to "GET".
...

Name-value pairs giving API parameters. Will be matched into endpoint placeholders, sent as query parameters in GET requests, and as a JSON body of POST requests. If there is only one unnamed parameter, and it is a raw vector, then it will not be JSON encoded, but sent as raw data, as is. This can be used for example to add assets to releases. Named NULL values are silently dropped, and named NA values trigger an error.
per_page

Number of items to return per page. If omitted, will be substituted by max(.limit, 100) if .limit is set, otherwise determined by the API (never greater than 100).
.token

Authentication token. Defaults to GITHUB_PAT or GITHUB_TOKEN environment variables, in this order if any is set. See gh_token() if you need more flexibility, e.g. different tokens for different GitHub Enterprise deployments.
.destfile

Path to write response to disk. If NULL (default), response will be processed and returned as an object. If path is given, response will be written to disk in the form sent.
.overwrite

If .destfile is provided, whether to overwrite an existing file. Defaults to FALSE.
.api_url

Github API url (default: https://api.github.com). Used if endpoint just contains a path. Defaults to GITHUB_API_URL environment variable if set.
.method

HTTP method to use if not explicitly supplied in the endpoint.
.limit

Number of records to return. This can be used instead of manual pagination. By default it is NULL, which means that the defaults of the GitHub API are used. You can set it to a number to request more (or less) records, and also to Inf to request all records. Note, that if you request many records, then multiple GitHub API calls are used to get them, and this can take a potentially long time.
.accept

The value of the Accept HTTP header. Defaults to "application/vnd.github.v3+json" . If Accept is given in .send_headers, then that will be used. This parameter can be used to provide a custom media type, in order to access a preview feature of the API.
.send_headers

Named character vector of header field values (except Authorization, which is handled via .token). This can be used to override or augment the default User-Agent header: "https://github.com/r-lib/gh".
.progress

Whether to show a progress indicator for calls that need more than one HTTP request.

Value

Answer from the API as a gh_response object, which is also a list. Failed requests will generate an R error. Requests that generate a raw response will return a raw vector.

See also

gh_gql() if you want to use the GitHub GraphQL API, gh_whoami() for details on GitHub API token management.

Examples

if (identical(Sys.getenv("IN_PKGDOWN"), "true")) (if (getRversion() >= "3.4") withAutoprint else force)({ # examplesIf
## Repositories of a user, these are equivalent
gh("/users/hadley/repos")
gh("/users/{username}/repos", username = "hadley")

## Starred repositories of a user
gh("/users/hadley/starred")
gh("/users/{username}/starred", username = "hadley")
}) # examplesIf
#> > gh("/users/hadley/repos")
#> [
#>   {
#>     "id": 40423928,
#>     "node_id": "MDEwOlJlcG9zaXRvcnk0MDQyMzkyOA==",

if (FALSE) (if (getRversion() >= "3.4") withAutoprint else force)({ # examplesIf
## Create a repository, needs a token in GITHUB_PAT (or GITHUB_TOKEN)
## environment variable
gh("POST /user/repos", name = "foobar")
}) # examplesIf
if (identical(Sys.getenv("IN_PKGDOWN"), "true")) (if (getRversion() >= "3.4") withAutoprint else force)({ # examplesIf
## Issues of a repository
gh("/repos/hadley/dplyr/issues")
gh("/repos/{owner}/{repo}/issues", owner = "hadley", repo = "dplyr")

## Automatic pagination
users <- gh("/users", .limit = 50)
length(users)
}) # examplesIf

#>     "body": "There is unexpected behavior when using `safely()`, `mutate()`, and `options(warn = 2)` together:\r\n\r\n``` r\r\nlibrary(purrr)\r\nsuppressMessages(library(dplyr))\r\n\r\nerr_fun <- function (...) {\r\n  stop(\"this is fine\")\r\n}\r\n\r\nerr_fun_opts <- function (...) {\r\n  options(warn = 2)\r\n  warning(\"throws only in mutate()\")\r\n  options(warn = 1)\r\n}\r\n\r\n# normal results\r\nsafely(err_fun)()\r\n#> $result\r\n#> NULL\r\n#> \r\n#> $error\r\n#> <simpleError in .f(...): this is fine>\r\n\r\nsafely(err_fun_opts)()\r\n#> $result\r\n#> NULL\r\n#> \r\n#> $error\r\n#> <simpleError in .f(...): (converted from warning) throws only in mutate()>\r\n\r\nmutate(mtcars, test = list(safely(err_fun)()))$test[[1]]\r\n#> $result\r\n#> NULL\r\n#> \r\n#> $error\r\n#> <simpleError in .f(...): this is fine>\r\n\r\n\r\n# weird results\r\nmutate(mtcars, test = list(safely(err_fun_opts)()))\r\n#> Error: (converted from warning) Problem with `mutate()` input `test`.\r\n#> ℹ throws only in mutate()\r\n#> ℹ Input `test` is `list(safely(err_fun_opts)())`.\r\n```\r\n<sup>Created on 2020-08-31 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)<\/sup>\r\n\r\nIt seems possible this is a purrr issue, but I'm starting here since I only have problems inside `mutate()`.\r\n\r\n---\r\n\r\nVersion info:\r\n\r\n```\r\nR 4.0.2\r\npurrr 0.3.4\r\ndplyr 1.0.2\r\n```\r\n",

#>     "author_association": "NONE",
#>     "active_lock_reason": {},
#>     "body": "I ran into inability to use `!!as.name()` with `.x` or `.y` input variables inside of `mutate( map2( rename(...) )`.\r\nI provide a reprex with several attempts below.\r\n\r\nAlso I would like to add it is very strange but `.x` and `.y` _global_ variables are _not visible_ on the Environment tab in Data or Values sections in RStudio 1.3.1073. It is a problem if you used them for debugging previously without further `rm()`. The only way to know about their presence is to print them in the console.\r\n``` r\r\nlibrary(tidyverse)\r\n\r\ndf <- tibble(\r\n  var_name = \"new_name\",\r\n  data = list(data.frame(foo = 1))\r\n)\r\n\r\ndf\r\n#> # A tibble: 1 x 2\r\n#>   var_name data            \r\n#>   <chr>    <list>          \r\n#> 1 new_name <df[,1] [1 x 1]>\r\n\r\ndf$data\r\n#> [[1]]\r\n#>   foo\r\n#> 1   1\r\n\r\n# OK example 1\r\ndf %>% mutate(data = map2(data, var_name, ~.x %>% mutate(foo = .y))) %>% .$data\r\n#> [[1]]\r\n#>        foo\r\n#> 1 new_name\r\n\r\n# OK example 2\r\ndf %>% mutate(data = map(data, ~.x %>% rename(!!as.name(\"new_name\") := foo))) %>% .$data\r\n#> [[1]]\r\n#>   new_name\r\n#> 1        1\r\n\r\n# ERROR example 1\r\ndf %>% mutate(data = map2(data, \"new_name\", ~.x %>% rename(!!as.name(.y) := foo)))\r\n#> Error in as.name(.y): object '.y' not found\r\n\r\n# ERROR example 2\r\ndf %>% mutate(data = map2(data, var_name, ~.x %>% rename(!!as.name(.y) := foo)))\r\n#> Error in as.name(.y): object '.y' not found\r\n\r\n# ERROR example 3\r\ndf %>% mutate(data = map2(var_name, data, ~.y %>% rename(!!as.name(.x) := foo)))\r\n#> Error in as.name(.x): object '.x' not found\r\n\r\n# Example with global .y value 1\r\n.y <- \"global\"\r\ndf %>% mutate(data = map2(data, var_name, ~.x %>% rename(!!as.name(.y) := foo))) %>% .$data\r\n#> [[1]]\r\n#>   global\r\n#> 1      1\r\n\r\n# Example with global .y value 2\r\n.y <- list(\"a\")\r\ndf %>% mutate(data = map2(data, var_name, ~.x %>% rename(!!as.name(.y) := foo))) %>% .$data\r\n#> Error in as.name(.y): invalid type/length (symbol/1) in vector allocation\r\n\r\n# repeating ERROR example 2\r\nrm(.y)\r\ndf %>% mutate(data = map2(data, var_name, ~.x %>% rename(!!as.name(.y) := foo))) %>% .$data\r\n#> Error in as.name(.y): object '.y' not found\r\n```\r\n<sup>Created on 2020-09-01 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)<\/sup>",

#>     "closed_at": {},
#>     "author_association": "NONE",
#>     "active_lock_reason": {},
#>     "body": "As per title, we're developing a package where we use a structure that inherits from tibble, defined as follows:\r\n\r\n```{r}\r\nnew_ISADataFrame <- function(x,\r\n    mandVars = c(\"chr\", \"integration_locus\", \"strand\"),\r\n    meta = character(), ..., class = character()) {\r\n    stopifnot(is.list(x))\r\n    minLength <- min(vapply(x, length, FUN.VALUE = numeric(1)))\r\n\r\n    tibble::new_tibble(x,\r\n        mandatoryVars = mandVars,\r\n        metadata = meta, ...,\r\n        nrow = minLength, class = c(class, \"ISADataFrame\")\r\n    )\r\n}\r\n```\r\nUnfortunately when performing grouping on this structure, class isn't preserved and we've found no proper way to implement group_by generic, we've tried this:\r\n\r\n```{r}\r\nnew_grouped_ISAdf <- function(x, groups, ..., class = character()) {\r\n    stopifnot(is.ISADataFrame(x))\r\n    dplyr::new_grouped_df(x, groups, ..., class = c(class, \"ISADataFrame\"))\r\n}\r\n\r\nvalidate_grouped_ISAdf <- function(x, check_bounds = FALSE) {\r\n    dplyr::validate_grouped_df(x, check_bounds)\r\n}\r\n\r\ngrouped_ISAdf <- function(data, vars,\r\n                          drop = dplyr::group_by_drop_default(data)) {\r\n    if (!is.data.frame(data)) {\r\n        rlang::abort(\"`data` must be a data frame.\")\r\n    }\r\n    if (!is.character(vars)) {\r\n        rlang::abort(\"`vars` must be a character vector.\")\r\n    }\r\n\r\n    if (length(vars) == 0) {\r\n        ISADataFrame(data)\r\n    } else {\r\n        groups <- compute_groups(data, vars, drop = drop) #This is not an exported function\r\n        new_grouped_ISAdf(data, groups)\r\n    }\r\n}\r\n\r\ngroup_by.ISADataFrame <- function(.data, ...,\r\n                                  .add = FALSE,\r\n                                  .drop = dplyr::group_by_drop_default(.data)) {\r\n    groups <- dplyr::group_by_prepare(.data, ..., .add = .add)\r\n    grouped_ISAdf(groups$data, groups$group_names, .drop)\r\n}\r\n```\r\nBut as you can see `compute_groups` is not an exported function from dplyr. Is there any proper way to do this or could this function be exported so we can call it in our implementation?",
#>     "performed_via_github_app": {}
#>   },
#>   {

#>     "body": "So `sample_n` has been superseded in favour of `slice_sample`. \r\n\r\nI want to sample 50% of each group with atleast 1 sample from each group. This is easy to do with `slice_sample` with `prop = 0.5` but certain groups have only 1 row which are dropped. I want to make sure that atleast 1 row is selected from each group. \r\n\r\nConsider this example, \r\n\r\n```\r\ndf <- data.frame(col1 = c('a', 'b', 'b', 'c'), col2 = 1:4)\r\n```\r\n\r\nWith `sample_n`, I could do : \r\n\r\n```\r\ndf %>% group_by(col1) %>% sample_n(max(n() * 0.5, 1))\r\n```\r\n\r\nHowever, with `slice_sample` this fails : \r\n\r\n```\r\ndf %>% group_by(col1) %>% slice_sample(n = max(n() * 0.5,1))\r\n```\r\n\r\nreturns an error\r\n>Error: `n()` must only be used inside dplyr verbs.\r\n\r\nAm I missing something or this is a bug?",

#>     "closed_at": {},

#>     "active_lock_reason": {},
#>     "body": "I think this is a bug and not intended behaviour. Here's the reprex\r\n\r\n```r\r\ntibble(\r\n\tx = c(1,2)\r\n\t, y = c(3,4)\r\n\t, z = c(5,6)\r\n) %>% \r\n\tdplyr::group_by(y) %>%  #pre-existing grouping\r\n\tdplyr::group_by(across(any_of(c('y','z')))) %>% #tidyselect-specified grouping, \r\n\tdplyr::group_vars() \r\n```\r\nThis yields the value `\"z\"` instead of the expected `c(\"y\",\"z\")`. Simple solution is to always ungroup before grouping, but I thought you might want to be aware of this behaviour as it took me a while to work out that this was the culprit for some broken code.\r\n\r\n```\r\n> sessionInfo()\r\nR version 4.0.2 (2020-06-22)\r\nPlatform: x86_64-pc-linux-gnu (64-bit)\r\nRunning under: Ubuntu 20.04.1 LTS\r\n\r\nMatrix products: default\r\nBLAS:   /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/blas/libblas.so.3.9.0\r\nLAPACK: /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/lapack/liblapack.so.3.9.0\r\n\r\nlocale:\r\n [1] LC_CTYPE=en_CA.UTF-8       LC_NUMERIC=C              \r\n [3] LC_TIME=en_CA.UTF-8        LC_COLLATE=en_CA.UTF-8    \r\n [5] LC_MONETARY=en_CA.UTF-8    LC_MESSAGES=en_CA.UTF-8   \r\n [7] LC_PAPER=en_CA.UTF-8       LC_NAME=C                 \r\n [9] LC_ADDRESS=C               LC_TELEPHONE=C            \r\n[11] LC_MEASUREMENT=en_CA.UTF-8 LC_IDENTIFICATION=C       \r\n\r\nattached base packages:\r\n[1] stats     graphics  grDevices utils     datasets  methods   base     \r\n\r\nother attached packages:\r\n[1] forcats_0.5.0   stringr_1.4.0   dplyr_1.0.1     purrr_0.3.4     readr_1.3.1    \r\n[6] tidyr_1.1.1     tibble_3.0.3    ggplot2_3.3.2 lubridate_1.7.9 \r\n [9] jsonlite_1.7.0   lifecycle_0.2.0  gtable_0.3.0     pkgconfig_2.0.3 \r\n[13] rlang_0.4.7      reprex_0.3.0     cli_2.0.2        DBI_1.1.0       \r\n[17] rstudioapi_0.11  haven_2.3.1      xfun_0.16        withr_2.2.0     \r\n[21] xml2_1.3.2       httr_1.4.2       fs_1.4.2         generics_0.0.2  \r\n[25] vctrs_0.3.2      hms_0.5.3        grid_4.0.2       tidyselect_1.1.0\r\n[29] glue_1.4.1       R6_2.4.1         fansi_0.4.1      readxl_1.3.1    \r\n[33] modelr_0.1.8     blob_1.2.1       magrittr_1.5     backports_1.1.8 \r\n[37] scales_1.1.1     ellipsis_0.3.1   rvest_0.3.6      assertthat_0.2.1\r\n[41] colorspace_1.4-1 tinytex_0.25     stringi_1.4.6    munsell_0.5.0   \r\n[45] broom_0.7.0      crayon_1.3.4    \r\n```",

#>     "assignees": [],
#>     "milestone": {},

#>     "closed_at": {},
#>     "author_association": "NONE",
#>     "active_lock_reason": {},
#>     "body": "When data is grouped with the argument `.drop = FALSE` and the grouping variable is an ordered factor, the `summarise()` function converts the ordered factor to an unordered factor in the resulting data frame. The same is true when using `count(..., .drop = FALSE)`. \r\n\r\nIs there some way to preserve the original class of the grouping variable, or is this an ordered factor bug? Thank you!\r\n\r\n``` r\r\nlibrary(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE)\r\n#> Warning: package 'dplyr' was built under R version 4.0.2\r\npackageVersion(\"dplyr\")\r\n#> [1] '1.0.1'\r\npackageVersion(\"vctrs\")\r\n#> [1] '0.3.2'\r\nmtcars %>%\r\n  as_tibble() %>%\r\n  mutate(cyl = factor(cyl, ordered = TRUE)) %>% # making cyl ordered factor\r\n  group_by(cyl, .drop = FALSE) %>%\r\n  summarize(n = n())\r\n#> `summarise()` ungrouping output (override with `.groups` argument)\r\n#> # A tibble: 3 x 2\r\n#>   cyl       n\r\n#>   <fct> <int>\r\n#> 1 4        11\r\n#> 2 6         7\r\n#> 3 8        14\r\n```\r\n\r\n<sup>Created on 2020-08-02 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)<\/sup>\r\n",
#>     "performed_via_github_app": {}
#>   },
#>   {

#>     "body": "The description for `inner_join` and `full_join` are the same - indicating that all rows from x and y are joined. This is not the case with an `inner_join`. I have updated the description to highlight the fact that an `inner_join` only joins all rows from x and y **where there is a match in the key**.",

#>     "body": "This example on [colwise vignette](https://dplyr.tidyverse.org/articles/colwise.html) also calculates `max()` of `min()`ed values (`max_min_*`), which I don't think is intended. This made me think `across()` should have some option to distinguish the columns that is generated by `across()`. Is it technically possible...?\r\n\r\n``` r\r\nstarwars %>% summarise(\r\n  across(where(is.numeric), ~min(.x, na.rm = TRUE), .names = \"min_{col}\"),\r\n  across(where(is.numeric), ~max(.x, na.rm = TRUE), .names = \"max_{col}\")\r\n)\r\n#> # A tibble: 1 x 9\r\n#>   min_height min_mass min_birth_year max_height max_mass max_birth_year\r\n#>        <int>    <dbl>          <dbl>      <int>    <dbl>          <dbl>\r\n#> 1         66       15              8        264     1358            896\r\n#> # … with 3 more variables: max_min_height <int>, max_min_mass <dbl>,\r\n#> #   max_min_birth_year <dbl>\r\n```",

#>       {
#>         "id": 1257707950,
#>         "node_id": "MDU6TGFiZWwxMjU3NzA3OTUw",
#>         "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr/labels/join%20:twisted_rightwards_arrows:",
#>         "name": "join :twisted_rightwards_arrows:",
#>         "color": "eeeeee",
#>         "default": false,
#>         "description": "Related to joins"
#>       }
#>     ],
#>     "state": "open",
#>     "locked": false,
#>     "assignee": {},
#>     "assignees": [],
#>     "milestone": {},
#>     "comments": 3,
#>     "created_at": "2020-07-19T23:56:19Z",
#>     "updated_at": "2020-08-31T10:23:02Z",
#>     "closed_at": {},
#>     "author_association": "NONE",
#>     "active_lock_reason": {},
#>     "body": "Hi, \r\n\r\nIt would be great if join commands had the possibility to update values. \r\n\r\nFor example, I am working with data frame \"m\" and want to update the \"x\" values for some NA cases using another data frame \"y\".  Join commands will generate two columns x.x and x.y. Then, I would have to mutate values to update variables in this new, larger data.frame. \r\n\r\nHowever, if there was an update = T option, the new data.frame could automatically update NA values from the master data-set with the columns that have the same name in the using data set. Then, no new columns will be generated, I will be working in a smaller data-set and there would be no need to do any extra steps. \r\n\r\nThere could also be a conflict option to also manage the cases in which there are values in both the master and using data set. For example, if conflict = F, then when there are values in both master and using values then master data is retained, and nothing is changed in the column for rows that are present in master and using data. However, if conflict = T then the data from the using data set is retained. \r\n\r\nIn STATA this is part of the  [merge](https://www.stata.com/manuals13/dmerge.pdf) command. Some people have been asking the same and making some workarounds [example](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/51572462/update-replace-values-in-dataframe-with-tidyverse-join). \r\n \r\nThank you once again for dplyr.\r\n\r\n```r\r\nm <- data.frame(id  = c(1,2,3), x = c(4, 4, NA))\r\nu <- data.frame(id  = c(1,2,3), x = c(5, 5, 5))\r\n\r\n# Current results\r\nm %>% full_join(u, by = \"id\")\r\n\r\n# With update = T we want:\r\ndata.frame(id  = c(1,2,3), x  = c(4,4,5))\r\n\r\n# With update = T and conflict = T we want:\r\ndata.frame(id  = c(1,2,3), x  = c(5,5,5))\r\n# With update = T and conflict = F we want:\r\ndata.frame(id  = c(1,2,3), x  = c(4,4,5))\r\n\r\n\r\n```\r\n",

#>     "author_association": "NONE",
#>     "active_lock_reason": {},
#>     "body": "---\r\n\r\nHey! I know that row names on tibbles are deprecated (which I disagree with but that is beside the point) but I think that for now, given that someone wants to continue using this deprecated feature, functions like mutate should not drop rownames in cases by default where the user wants to keep them.  There are constructs outside of the tidyverse that still use rownames; for example the bioconductor object 'eset' uses them in important ways and there are tools that take esets and not more modern bioconductor objects.   So if I want to use tibbles and dplyr verbs when constructing esets I have to do inconvenient workarounds, or not use dplyr.   So what I want is for tidyverse functions to preserve rownames wherever possible, even though I know it is not possible with certain things (like joins where rows are added). \r\n\r\n\r\nHere is a simple example: \r\n```r\r\nlibrary(tidyverse)\r\nsmall_tibble <- mpg[1:3,1:3]\r\nrownames(small_tibble) <- c(\"snap\",\"cracke\",\"pop\")\r\nprint(rownames(small_tibble)) #setting rownames was successful\r\nsmall_tibble_mutated <- small_tibble %>% mutate(displ = displ^2)\r\nprint(rownames(small_tibble_mutated)) #rownames disappeared\r\n```\r\n",

#>     "locked": false,
#>     "assignee": {},
#>     "assignees": [],
#>     "milestone": {},
#>     "comments": 0,
#>     "created_at": "2020-07-15T20:41:24Z",
#>     "updated_at": "2020-08-11T09:37:34Z",
#>     "closed_at": {},
#>     "author_association": "NONE",
#>     "active_lock_reason": {},
#>     "body": "It would be incredible if you could specify which kind of duplicates in the join variable(s) is(are) acceptable as in [the STATA merge command](https://www.stata.com/manuals13/dmerge.pdf). \r\n\r\nThis means having the possibility to decide whether it's ok to have: \r\n- Duplicates in the join variables of the master data but not in the join variables of the using data (a m:1 join)\r\n- Duplicates in the join variables of the using data but not in the join variables of the master data (a 1:m join)\r\n- Duplicates in both cases (an m:m join)\r\n- No duplicates (a 1:1 join)\r\n\r\nI work in education, and some times data-sets were poorly digitized because some students appear to have been enrolled in more than one school (duplicates in the join variable).  When that happens both in the master and using data, those students multiply exponentially in the resulting data-frame, as it happens now with, for example, left_join.  You may not want that. Also, if you are not cautious enough, you may not pay attention to duplicate students, that \"ninjaly\" add more observations to your results. \r\n\r\nSTATA used to have the same issue and only had two commands \"merge\" or \"join\" somehow similar to R, and did not let you decide when duplicates are acceptable (i.e duplicate information in the using data when merging students to school characteristics, school id is the join variable) and when it may not be acceptable (i.e duplicate information in the master and using data when merging a student list to a student characteristic, student id is the join variable). At some point, they made that feature feasible and it's great because it allows you to merge and make quality control in one single step. \r\n\r\nThank you for your time and amazing work. Hope this helps. \r\n",
#>     "performed_via_github_app": {}
#>   },
#>   {
#>     "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/5369",
#>     "repository_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr",

#>     "id": 647749307,
#>     "node_id": "MDU6SXNzdWU2NDc3NDkzMDc=",
#>     "number": 5369,
#>     "title": "Inconsistent and unpredictable behaviour from group_by with .drop=FALSE",
#>     "user": {
#>       "login": "pitakakariki",
#>       "id": 1023705,
#>       "node_id": "MDQ6VXNlcjEwMjM3MDU=",
#>       "avatar_url": "https://avatars0.githubusercontent.com/u/1023705?v=4",
#>       "gravatar_id": "",
#>       "url": "https://api.github.com/users/pitakakariki",
#>       "html_url": "https://github.com/pitakakariki",
#>       "followers_url": "https://api.github.com/users/pitakakariki/followers",
#>       "following_url": "https://api.github.com/users/pitakakariki/following{/other_user}",
#>       "gists_url": "https://api.github.com/users/pitakakariki/gists{/gist_id}",
#>       "starred_url": "https://api.github.com/users/pitakakariki/starred{/owner}{/repo}",
#>       "subscriptions_url": "https://api.github.com/users/pitakakariki/subscriptions",
#>       "organizations_url": "https://api.github.com/users/pitakakariki/orgs",
#>       "repos_url": "https://api.github.com/users/pitakakariki/repos",
#>       "events_url": "https://api.github.com/users/pitakakariki/events{/privacy}",
#>       "received_events_url": "https://api.github.com/users/pitakakariki/received_events",
#>       "type": "User",
#>       "site_admin": false
#>     },
#>     "labels": [],
#>     "state": "open",
#>     "locked": false,
#>     "assignee": {},
#>     "assignees": [],
#>     "milestone": {},
#>     "comments": 7,
#>     "created_at": "2020-06-30T00:10:09Z",
#>     "updated_at": "2020-08-31T13:04:32Z",
#>     "closed_at": {},
#>     "author_association": "NONE",
#>     "active_lock_reason": {},
#>     "body": "The effect of the `.drop=FALSE` argument to `group_by` depends on whether the grouping variables are explicitly factors or not.\r\n\r\n``` r\r\nlibrary(dplyr, warn.conflicts=FALSE)\r\n\r\nmtcars %>%\r\n  \r\n  group_by(gear, am, .drop=FALSE) %>%\r\n  \r\n  summarise(count=n(), .groups=\"drop\")\r\n#> # A tibble: 4 x 3\r\n#>    gear    am count\r\n#>   <dbl> <dbl> <int>\r\n#> 1     3     0    15\r\n#> 2     4     0     4\r\n#> 3     4     1     8\r\n#> 4     5     1     5\r\n\r\nmtcars %>%\r\n  \r\n  mutate(am=as.factor(am)) %>%\r\n  \r\n  group_by(gear, am, .drop=FALSE) %>%\r\n  \r\n  summarise(count=n(), .groups=\"drop\")\r\n#> # A tibble: 6 x 3\r\n#>    gear am    count\r\n#>   <dbl> <fct> <int>\r\n#> 1     3 0        15\r\n#> 2     3 1         0\r\n#> 3     4 0         4\r\n#> 4     4 1         8\r\n#> 5     5 0         0\r\n#> 6     5 1         5\r\n```\r\n\r\n<sup>Created on 2020-06-30 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)<\/sup>\r\n\r\nSince all grouping variables are either explicitly or impicitly factors, I would expect similar behaviour in each case (unless there are additional values encoded in `levels` but not seen in the data, which is not the case here).\r\n\r\nSome combinations of implicit and explicit factors give very strange results (note that there are no `NA`'s in `mtcars`):\r\n\r\n``` r\r\nlibrary(dplyr, warn.conflicts=FALSE)\r\n\r\nmtcars %>%\r\n  \r\n  mutate(am=as.factor(am)) %>%\r\n  \r\n  group_by(gear, am, cyl, .drop=FALSE) %>%\r\n  \r\n  summarise(count=n(), .groups=\"drop\")\r\n#> # A tibble: 12 x 4\r\n#>     gear am      cyl count\r\n#>    <dbl> <fct> <dbl> <int>\r\n#>  1     3 0         4     1\r\n#>  2     3 0         6     2\r\n#>  3     3 0         8    12\r\n#>  4     3 1        NA     0\r\n#>  5     4 0         4     2\r\n#>  6     4 0         6     2\r\n#>  7     4 1         4     6\r\n#>  8     4 1         6     2\r\n#>  9     5 0        NA     0\r\n#> 10     5 1         4     2\r\n#> 11     5 1         6     1\r\n#> 12     5 1         8     2\r\n```\r\n\r\n<sup>Created on 2020-06-30 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)<\/sup>\r\n\r\nTo be absolutely clear, you can recover the intended and expected behaviour in these cases by converting all of the grouping variables to explicit factors:\r\n\r\n``` r\r\nlibrary(dplyr, warn.conflicts=FALSE)\r\n\r\nmtcars %>%\r\n  \r\n  mutate(gear=as.factor(gear), am=as.factor(am)) %>%\r\n  \r\n  group_by(gear, am, .drop=FALSE) %>%\r\n  \r\n  summarise(count=n(), .groups=\"drop\")\r\n#> # A tibble: 6 x 3\r\n#>   gear  am    count\r\n#>   <fct> <fct> <int>\r\n#> 1 3     0        15\r\n#> 2 3     1         0\r\n#> 3 4     0         4\r\n#> 4 4     1         8\r\n#> 5 5     0         0\r\n#> 6 5     1         5\r\n\r\nmtcars %>%\r\n  \r\n  mutate(gear=as.factor(gear), am=as.factor(am), cyl=as.factor(cyl)) %>%\r\n  \r\n  group_by(gear, am, cyl, .drop=FALSE) %>%\r\n  \r\n  summarise(count=n(), .groups=\"drop\")\r\n#> # A tibble: 18 x 4\r\n#>    gear  am    cyl   count\r\n#>    <fct> <fct> <fct> <int>\r\n#>  1 3     0     4         1\r\n#>  2 3     0     6         2\r\n#>  3 3     0     8        12\r\n#>  4 3     1     4         0\r\n#>  5 3     1     6         0\r\n#>  6 3     1     8         0\r\n#>  7 4     0     4         2\r\n#>  8 4     0     6         2\r\n#>  9 4     0     8         0\r\n#> 10 4     1     4         6\r\n#> 11 4     1     6         2\r\n#> 12 4     1     8         0\r\n#> 13 5     0     4         0\r\n#> 14 5     0     6         0\r\n#> 15 5     0     8         0\r\n#> 16 5     1     4         2\r\n#> 17 5     1     6         1\r\n#> 18 5     1     8         2\r\n```\r\n\r\n<sup>Created on 2020-06-30 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)<\/sup>\r\n",

#>       {
#>         "id": 17708200,

#>         "description": ""

#>     ],
#>     "state": "open",
#>     "locked": false,
#>     "assignee": {},
#>     "assignees": [],
#>     "milestone": {},
#>     "comments": 4,
#>     "created_at": "2020-06-04T12:34:44Z",
#>     "updated_at": "2020-07-01T11:16:27Z",
#>     "closed_at": {},
#>     "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
#>     "active_lock_reason": {},
#>     "body": "A really useful feature of `sample_n()` is the ability to vary `size` by the grouping variable(s):\r\n\r\n```r\r\nlibrary(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE)\r\npackageVersion(\"dplyr\")\r\n#> [1] '1.0.0'\r\n\r\nset.seed(123223)\r\n\r\nstarwars %>%\r\n  select(name, sex, homeworld) %>%\r\n  add_count(sex, homeworld, name = \"number\") %>%\r\n  group_by(sex, homeworld) %>%\r\n  sample_n(size = case_when(\r\n    number %in% 1:4 ~ 1,\r\n    number >= 5 ~ 2\r\n  )) %>%\r\n  ungroup() %>%\r\n  arrange(desc(number), homeworld)\r\n#> # A tibble: 64 x 4\r\n#>    name                sex    homeworld number\r\n#>    <chr>               <chr>  <chr>      <int>\r\n#>  1 Owen Lars           male   Tatooine       6\r\n#>  2 Darth Vader         male   Tatooine       6\r\n#>  3 Jar Jar Binks       male   Naboo          5\r\n#>  4 Rugor Nass          male   Naboo          5\r\n#>  5 Finn                male   <NA>           5\r\n#>  6 Yoda                male   <NA>           5\r\n#>  7 Dormé               female Naboo          3\r\n#>  8 BB8                 none   <NA>           3\r\n#>  9 Bail Prestor Organa male   Alderaan       2\r\n#> 10 Wedge Antilles      male   Corellia       2\r\n#> # … with 54 more rows\r\n```\r\n\r\nSwitching to `sample_n()`'s successor `slice_sample()` yields a different number of rows:\r\n\r\n```r\r\nlibrary(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE)\r\npackageVersion(\"dplyr\")\r\n#> [1] '1.0.0'\r\n\r\nset.seed(123223)\r\n\r\nstarwars %>%\r\n  select(name, sex, homeworld) %>%\r\n  add_count(sex, homeworld, name = \"number\") %>%\r\n  group_by(sex, homeworld) %>%\r\n  slice_sample(n = case_when(\r\n    \"number\" %in% 1:4 ~ 1,\r\n    \"number\" >= 5 ~ 2\r\n  )) %>%\r\n  ungroup() %>%\r\n  arrange(desc(number), homeworld)\r\n#> # A tibble: 75 x 4\r\n#>    name              sex    homeworld number\r\n#>    <chr>             <chr>  <chr>      <int>\r\n#>  1 Cliegg Lars       male   Tatooine       6\r\n#>  2 Biggs Darklighter male   Tatooine       6\r\n#>  3 Palpatine         male   Naboo          5\r\n#>  4 Rugor Nass        male   Naboo          5\r\n#>  5 Qui-Gon Jinn      male   <NA>           5\r\n#>  6 Finn              male   <NA>           5\r\n#>  7 Dormé             female Naboo          3\r\n#>  8 Padmé Amidala     female Naboo          3\r\n#>  9 R4-P17            none   <NA>           3\r\n#> 10 BB8               none   <NA>           3\r\n#> # … with 65 more rows\r\n```\r\n\r\n`sample_n()` is behaving as I would expect: returning one sample per combination of `sex` and `homeworld` when said combination occurs between 1 and 4 times; and two samples per combination when there are 5 or more occurrences.\r\n\r\nMaybe I'm doing something wrong, but `slice_sample()` is returning two samples for all combinations of `sex` and `homeworld`, regardless of the number of times said combination occurs, except for combinations which only occur once, which can only return one sample.",

#>       "created_at": "2020-03-22T09:33:34Z",

#>       "closed_at": {}

#>     "comments": 4,

#>     "closed_at": {},
#>     "author_association": "NONE",
#>     "active_lock_reason": {},
#>     "body": "According to the documentation, `select()` should preserve attributes (\"Data frame attributes are preserved.\" in section Value). However, this seems to work only for tibbles, not for data frames. This is an reproducible example:\r\n\r\n```\r\nmtcars_df <- mtcars\r\nattr(mtcars_df, \"test\") <- TRUE\r\nmtcars_tib <- as_tibble(mtcars_df)\r\nattr(mtcars_df, \"test\")\r\nattr(mtcars_tib, \"test\")\r\n\r\nattr(dplyr::select(mtcars_df), \"test\")\r\nattr(dplyr::select(mtcars_tib), \"test\")\r\n```\r\n\r\nWith dplyr 0.8.5, all the four calls of `attr()` return `TRUE` as expected. But with dplyr 1.0.0, `attr(dplyr::select(mtcars_df), \"test\")` returns `NULL`.\r\n\r\nThe result does not change, if some columns are selected.",
#>     "performed_via_github_app": {}
#>   },
#>   {
#>     "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/5290",
#>     "repository_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr",
#>     "labels_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/5290/labels{/name}",
#>     "comments_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/5290/comments",
#>     "events_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/5290/events",
#>     "html_url": "https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/5290",
#>     "id": 628630066,
#>     "node_id": "MDU6SXNzdWU2Mjg2MzAwNjY=",
#>     "number": 5290,

#>     "body": "I am having a perf issue with across.\r\n\r\n2s versus 74s depending on the writing.\r\n\r\nMy dplyr version: 0.8.99.9003\r\n```r\r\nmun2014 <- vroom(\"https://data.regardscitoyens.org/elections/2014_municipales/MN14_Bvot_T1_01-49.txt\", \r\n                 col_select = -c('X4','X9','X10','X11'),\r\n                 col_names = FALSE, \r\n                 locale = locale(encoding = \"WINDOWS-1252\")) \r\n# 275000 obs, 9 variables\r\n\r\nsystem.time( dataag1 <- mun2014 %>%\r\n               group_by_if( is.character )  %>%\r\n               summarise_if( is_numeric, sum ) \r\n)\r\n# 1.4s\r\n\r\nsystem.time( dataag2 <- mun2014 %>%\r\n              group_by( across(where(is.character)) )  %>%\r\n              summarise( across(where(is_numeric), sum) ) \r\n)\r\n# 74 s\r\n\r\nall.equal(dataag1,dataag2)\r\n# true\r\n\r\n# by the way: is there a simplier manner to use across here?\r\n```\r\n",

#>     "author_association": "MEMBER",
#>     "active_lock_reason": {},
#>     "pull_request": {
#>       "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr/pulls/5262",
#>       "html_url": "https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/pull/5262",
#>       "diff_url": "https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/pull/5262.diff",
#>       "patch_url": "https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/pull/5262.patch"
#>     },
#>     "body": "``` r\r\nlibrary(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE)\r\n\r\ndf <- tibble(a = 1:4)\r\n\r\nslice(df, 1)\r\n#> # A tibble: 1 x 1\r\n#>       a\r\n#>   <int>\r\n#> 1     1\r\nslice(df, -1)\r\n#> # A tibble: 3 x 1\r\n#>       a\r\n#>   <int>\r\n#> 1     2\r\n#> 2     3\r\n#> 3     4\r\n\r\nslice(df, 5)\r\n#> Error: Can't subset elements that don't exist.\r\n#> x Location 5 doesn't exist.\r\n#> ℹ There are only 4 elements.\r\nslice(df, NA)\r\n#> # A tibble: 1 x 1\r\n#>       a\r\n#>   <int>\r\n#> 1    NA\r\nslice(df, c(NA, 1))\r\n#> # A tibble: 2 x 1\r\n#>       a\r\n#>   <int>\r\n#> 1    NA\r\n#> 2     1\r\n```\r\n\r\n<sup>Created on 2020-05-22 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)<\/sup>\r\n\r\nI guess this would need some way to forgive about out of bounds, and also disregard missing values. Same reprex on master: \r\n\r\n``` r\r\nlibrary(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE)\r\n\r\ndf <- tibble(a = 1:4)\r\n\r\nslice(df, 1)\r\n#> # A tibble: 1 x 1\r\n#>       a\r\n#>   <int>\r\n#> 1     1\r\nslice(df, -1)\r\n#> # A tibble: 3 x 1\r\n#>       a\r\n#>   <int>\r\n#> 1     2\r\n#> 2     3\r\n#> 3     4\r\n\r\nslice(df, 5)\r\n#> # A tibble: 0 x 1\r\n#> # … with 1 variable: a <int>\r\nslice(df, NA)\r\n#> # A tibble: 0 x 1\r\n#> # … with 1 variable: a <int>\r\nslice(df, c(NA, 1))\r\n#> # A tibble: 1 x 1\r\n#>       a\r\n#>   <int>\r\n#> 1     1\r\n```\r\n\r\n<sup>Created on 2020-05-22 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)<\/sup>\r\n\r\nI guess if we were to maintain current `slice()` choices, we would need: \r\n\r\n`num_as_location(missing = \"drop\", oob = \"drop\")` or something similar. @lionel- \r\n",

#>       {
#>         "id": 334471510,
#>         "node_id": "MDU6TGFiZWwzMzQ0NzE1MTA=",
#>         "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr/labels/verbs%20:running_woman:",

#>     ],
#>     "state": "open",
#>     "locked": false,
#>     "assignee": {},
#>     "assignees": [],
#>     "milestone": {},
#>     "comments": 3,
#>     "created_at": "2020-05-07T21:00:19Z",
#>     "updated_at": "2020-05-11T20:40:02Z",
#>     "closed_at": {},
#>     "author_association": "NONE",
#>     "active_lock_reason": {},
#>     "body": "A one-line reprex of this behavior is:\r\n\r\n``` r\r\ndplyr::rename(data.frame(old = 1), new = c(dud = \"old\"))\r\n#>   new...dud\r\n#> 1         1\r\n```\r\n\r\nThis is an issue if we have a function where data.frames with myriad names have their names changed to certain \"standard\" names. In the case below, I have a standard column-name `foo`, but a data.frame's called it `bar` instead, so we call the following function to give it the standard name\r\n\r\n``` r\r\nstandardize <- function(df, fooName) {\r\n  dplyr::rename(df, foo = !!fooName)\r\n}\r\n\r\nstandardize(data.frame(bar = 1), \"bar\")\r\n#>   foo\r\n#> 1   1\r\n```\r\n\r\n<sup>Created on 2020-05-07 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)<\/sup>\r\n\r\nThis works just fine.\r\n\r\nHowever, if, for whatever reason, the value passed to `fooName` is a length-1 named vector, we get the behavior shown at the start:\r\n\r\n``` r\r\nname <- c(buzz = \"bar\")\r\nstandardize(data.frame(bar = 1), name)\r\n#>   foo...buzz\r\n#> 1          1\r\n```\r\n\r\nThe vector's name is clumsily suffixed to the desired name with an ellipsis. Is this expected behavior? I'm currently solving this by using `foo = unname(fooName)`, which works, but wonder if this is just a bug.",
#>     "performed_via_github_app": {}
#>   },
#>   {
#>     "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/5184",
#>     "repository_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr",

#>     "html_url": "https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/5184",
#>     "id": 612025541,
#>     "node_id": "MDU6SXNzdWU2MTIwMjU1NDE=",
#>     "number": 5184,
#>     "title": "adjacency grouping as a helper function",
#>     "user": {
#>       "login": "r2evans",
#>       "id": 5815808,
#>       "node_id": "MDQ6VXNlcjU4MTU4MDg=",
#>       "avatar_url": "https://avatars0.githubusercontent.com/u/5815808?v=4",
#>       "gravatar_id": "",

#>     "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
#>     "active_lock_reason": {},
#>     "body": "This has been discussed in various issues and forums, notably:\r\n\r\n- https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/237, suggesting `group_by_adj()` (suggesting pre-ordered adjacency);\r\n- https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/1534;\r\n- https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/1661; and\r\n- https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/4445 (most recent)\r\n\r\nOne key difference is that some of those discussions focused on a new `group_by_*` verb, where I suggest having just a helper function is sufficient to scratch the itch sufficiently. Lacking safeguards and sanity checks, it could be as straight-forward as:\r\n\r\n```r\r\nrle_group <- function(...) {\r\n  yy <- rle(paste(...))\r\n  rep(seq_along(yy$lengths), yy$lengths)\r\n}\r\n\r\ndf <- data.frame(x = c(0, 0, 1, 0), y = c(2, 2, 2, 2))\r\ndf %>%\r\n  group_by(grp = rle_group(x, y))\r\n# # A tibble: 4 x 3\r\n# # Groups:   grp [3]\r\n#       x     y   grp\r\n#   <dbl> <dbl> <int>\r\n# 1     0     2     1\r\n# 2     0     2     1\r\n# 3     1     2     2\r\n# 4     0     2     3\r\n```\r\n\r\nThe under-inspiring `Groups: grp` may not be as informative as [Romain's previous suggestion](https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/237#issuecomment-35085223) of\r\n\r\n```lang-r\r\n> df <- data.frame( x = 1, a = rep(c(1,2), each = 4), b = rep( letters[1:2], each = 2), stringsAsFactors = TRUE )\r\n> gdf <- grouped_df_adj_impl( df, list( quote(x), quote(a), quote(b) ), FALSE )\r\n> summarise(gdf, n = n() )\r\nSource: local data frame [4 x 4]\r\nGroups: x, a\r\n\r\n  x a b n\r\n1 1 1 a 2\r\n2 1 1 b 2\r\n3 1 2 a 2\r\n4 1 2 b 2\r\n```\r\n\r\n(where the `Groups: x, a` is more useful), it still enables the grouping.\r\n\r\nThis comes up frequently enough on StackOverflow that I think its utility is justified. I think the implementation could be innocuous enough to not impact other verbs.\r\n\r\nThe use of `paste` enables \"one or more\" columns, and happens to side-step `rle`'s avoidance of `factor`. It does add overhead, so a more performant variant might be supported (that does not omit `factor`s). I'd think a variant of [Hadley's initial suggestion](https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/237#issuecomment-34117419) (Rcpp-based) could be adapted to handle one-or-more.\r\n\r\nI'd be willing to start on a PR if maintainers support the concept.",

#>     "body": "\r\nRunning a `summarise()` across a difftime variable on a grouped dataset has exceptionally poor performance. This is noticeable in that the poor performance doesn't occur in base R or data.table and also doesn't occur in dplyr if you cast the variable to numeric. \r\n\r\nRe-producible example below (using dplyr 0.8.5)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n```r\r\nn <- 2000000\r\nlibrary(dplyr)\r\nlibrary(data.table)\r\n\r\na = as.Date('2018-01-01')\r\nb = as.Date('2019-01-01')\r\n\r\ndat_num <- tibble(\r\n    patientid = sample( 1:50000, replace = TRUE, size = n ),\r\n    value = difftime(b, a, unit = \"days\")  %>% as.numeric()\r\n)\r\n\r\ndat_date <- tibble(\r\n    patientid = sample( 1:50000, replace = TRUE, size = n ),\r\n    value = difftime(b, a, unit = \"days\") \r\n)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n### Dplyr - numeric (quick)\r\nsystem.time({\r\n    dat_num %>%\r\n        group_by(patientid) %>%\r\n        summarise( m = max(value))\r\n})\r\n\r\n### Dplyr - difftime (takes forever to run) \r\nsystem.time({\r\n    dat_date %>%\r\n        group_by(patientid) %>%\r\n        summarise( m = max(value))\r\n})\r\n\r\n\r\n### Base R - numeric (quick)\r\nsystem.time({\r\n    tapply( X = dat_num$value, dat_num$patientid, max)\r\n})\r\n\r\n### Base R - difftime (quick)\r\nsystem.time({\r\n    tapply( X = dat_date$value, dat_date$patientid, max)\r\n})\r\n\r\n\r\n### data.table - numeric (quick)\r\nsystem.time({\r\n    x <- as.data.table(dat_num)\r\n    x[, .(m = max(value)), by = patientid]\r\n})\r\n\r\n### data.table - difftime (quick)\r\nsystem.time({\r\n    x <- as.data.table(dat_date)\r\n    x[, .(m = max(value)), by = patientid]\r\n})\r\n\r\n```\r\n\r\n\r\n```\r\nplatform       x86_64-apple-darwin15.6.0   \r\narch           x86_64                      \r\nos             darwin15.6.0                \r\nsystem         x86_64, darwin15.6.0        \r\nstatus                                     \r\nmajor          3                           \r\nminor          6.3                         \r\nyear           2020                        \r\nmonth          02                          \r\nday            29                          \r\nsvn rev        77875                       \r\nlanguage       R                           \r\nversion.string R version 3.6.3 (2020-02-29)\r\nnickname       Holding the Windsock \r\n```\r\n\r\n",

#>     "body": "There is unexpected behavior when using `safely()`, `mutate()`, and `options(warn = 2)` together:\r\n\r\n``` r\r\nlibrary(purrr)\r\nsuppressMessages(library(dplyr))\r\n\r\nerr_fun <- function (...) {\r\n  stop(\"this is fine\")\r\n}\r\n\r\nerr_fun_opts <- function (...) {\r\n  options(warn = 2)\r\n  warning(\"throws only in mutate()\")\r\n  options(warn = 1)\r\n}\r\n\r\n# normal results\r\nsafely(err_fun)()\r\n#> $result\r\n#> NULL\r\n#> \r\n#> $error\r\n#> <simpleError in .f(...): this is fine>\r\n\r\nsafely(err_fun_opts)()\r\n#> $result\r\n#> NULL\r\n#> \r\n#> $error\r\n#> <simpleError in .f(...): (converted from warning) throws only in mutate()>\r\n\r\nmutate(mtcars, test = list(safely(err_fun)()))$test[[1]]\r\n#> $result\r\n#> NULL\r\n#> \r\n#> $error\r\n#> <simpleError in .f(...): this is fine>\r\n\r\n\r\n# weird results\r\nmutate(mtcars, test = list(safely(err_fun_opts)()))\r\n#> Error: (converted from warning) Problem with `mutate()` input `test`.\r\n#> ℹ throws only in mutate()\r\n#> ℹ Input `test` is `list(safely(err_fun_opts)())`.\r\n```\r\n<sup>Created on 2020-08-31 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)<\/sup>\r\n\r\nIt seems possible this is a purrr issue, but I'm starting here since I only have problems inside `mutate()`.\r\n\r\n---\r\n\r\nVersion info:\r\n\r\n```\r\nR 4.0.2\r\npurrr 0.3.4\r\ndplyr 1.0.2\r\n```\r\n",

#>     "author_association": "NONE",
#>     "active_lock_reason": {},
#>     "body": "I ran into inability to use `!!as.name()` with `.x` or `.y` input variables inside of `mutate( map2( rename(...) )`.\r\nI provide a reprex with several attempts below.\r\n\r\nAlso I would like to add it is very strange but `.x` and `.y` _global_ variables are _not visible_ on the Environment tab in Data or Values sections in RStudio 1.3.1073. It is a problem if you used them for debugging previously without further `rm()`. The only way to know about their presence is to print them in the console.\r\n``` r\r\nlibrary(tidyverse)\r\n\r\ndf <- tibble(\r\n  var_name = \"new_name\",\r\n  data = list(data.frame(foo = 1))\r\n)\r\n\r\ndf\r\n#> # A tibble: 1 x 2\r\n#>   var_name data            \r\n#>   <chr>    <list>          \r\n#> 1 new_name <df[,1] [1 x 1]>\r\n\r\ndf$data\r\n#> [[1]]\r\n#>   foo\r\n#> 1   1\r\n\r\n# OK example 1\r\ndf %>% mutate(data = map2(data, var_name, ~.x %>% mutate(foo = .y))) %>% .$data\r\n#> [[1]]\r\n#>        foo\r\n#> 1 new_name\r\n\r\n# OK example 2\r\ndf %>% mutate(data = map(data, ~.x %>% rename(!!as.name(\"new_name\") := foo))) %>% .$data\r\n#> [[1]]\r\n#>   new_name\r\n#> 1        1\r\n\r\n# ERROR example 1\r\ndf %>% mutate(data = map2(data, \"new_name\", ~.x %>% rename(!!as.name(.y) := foo)))\r\n#> Error in as.name(.y): object '.y' not found\r\n\r\n# ERROR example 2\r\ndf %>% mutate(data = map2(data, var_name, ~.x %>% rename(!!as.name(.y) := foo)))\r\n#> Error in as.name(.y): object '.y' not found\r\n\r\n# ERROR example 3\r\ndf %>% mutate(data = map2(var_name, data, ~.y %>% rename(!!as.name(.x) := foo)))\r\n#> Error in as.name(.x): object '.x' not found\r\n\r\n# Example with global .y value 1\r\n.y <- \"global\"\r\ndf %>% mutate(data = map2(data, var_name, ~.x %>% rename(!!as.name(.y) := foo))) %>% .$data\r\n#> [[1]]\r\n#>   global\r\n#> 1      1\r\n\r\n# Example with global .y value 2\r\n.y <- list(\"a\")\r\ndf %>% mutate(data = map2(data, var_name, ~.x %>% rename(!!as.name(.y) := foo))) %>% .$data\r\n#> Error in as.name(.y): invalid type/length (symbol/1) in vector allocation\r\n\r\n# repeating ERROR example 2\r\nrm(.y)\r\ndf %>% mutate(data = map2(data, var_name, ~.x %>% rename(!!as.name(.y) := foo))) %>% .$data\r\n#> Error in as.name(.y): object '.y' not found\r\n```\r\n<sup>Created on 2020-09-01 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)<\/sup>",

#>     "body": "related to #5478\r\n\r\nTrying to be more informative in the error message: \r\n\r\n``` r\r\nlibrary(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE)\r\n\r\ndf <- data.frame(col1 = c('a', 'b', 'b', 'c'), col2 = 1:4)\r\ndf %>% \r\n  group_by(col1) %>% \r\n  slice_sample(n = max(n() * 0.5, 1))\r\n#> Error: `n` must be constant across groups in `slice_sample()`.\r\n#> x `n()` must only be used #>     "body": "As per title, we're developing a package where we use a structure that inherits from tibble, defined as follows:\r\n\r\n```{r}\r\nnew_ISADataFrame <- function(x,\r\n    mandVars = c(\"chr\", \"integration_locus\", \"strand\"),\r\n    meta = character(), ..., class = character()) {\r\n    stopifnot(is.list(x))\r\n    minLength <- min(vapply(x, length, FUN.VALUE = numeric(1)))\r\n\r\n    tibble::new_tibble(x,\r\n        mandatoryVars = mandVars,\r\n        metadata = meta, ...,\r\n        nrow = minLength, class = c(class, \"ISADataFrame\")\r\n    )\r\n}\r\n```\r\nUnfortunately when performing grouping on this structure, class isn't preserved and we've found no proper way to implement group_by generic, we've tried this:\r\n\r\n```{r}\r\nnew_grouped_ISAdf <- function(x, groups, ..., class = character()) {\r\n    stopifnot(is.ISADataFrame(x))\r\n    dplyr::new_grouped_df(x, groups, ..., class = c(class, \"ISADataFrame\"))\r\n}\r\n\r\nvalidate_grouped_ISAdf <- function(x, check_bounds = FALSE) {\r\n    dplyr::validate_grouped_df(x, check_bounds)\r\n}\r\n\r\ngrouped_ISAdf <- function(data, vars,\r\n                          drop = dplyr::group_by_drop_default(data)) {\r\n    if (!is.data.frame(data)) {\r\n        rlang::abort(\"`data` must be a data frame.\")\r\n    }\r\n    if (!is.character(vars)) {\r\n        rlang::abort(\"`vars` must be a character vector.\")\r\n    }\r\n\r\n    if (length(vars) == 0) {\r\n        ISADataFrame(data)\r\n    } else {\r\n        groups <- compute_groups(data, vars, drop = drop) #This is not an exported function\r\n        new_grouped_ISAdf(data, groups)\r\n    }\r\n}\r\n\r\ngroup_by.ISADataFrame <- function(.data, ...,\r\n                                  .add = FALSE,\r\n                                  .drop = dplyr::group_by_drop_default(.data)) {\r\n    groups <- dplyr::group_by_prepare(.data, ..., .add = .add)\r\n    grouped_ISAdf(groups$data, groups$group_names, .drop)\r\n}\r\n```\r\nBut as you can see `compute_groups` is not an exported function from dplyr. Is there any proper way to do this or could this function be exported so we can call it in our implementation?",

#>     "body": "So `sample_n` has been superseded in favour of `slice_sample`. \r\n\r\nI want to sample 50% of each group with atleast 1 sample from each group. This is easy to do with `slice_sample` with `prop = 0.5` but certain groups have only 1 row which are dropped. I want to make sure that atleast 1 row is selected from each group. \r\n\r\nConsider this example, \r\n\r\n```\r\ndf <- data.frame(col1 = c('a', 'b', 'b', 'c'), col2 = 1:4)\r\n```\r\n\r\nWith `sample_n`, I could do : \r\n\r\n```\r\ndf %>% group_by(col1) %>% sample_n(max(n() * 0.5, 1))\r\n```\r\n\r\nHowever, with `slice_sample` this fails : \r\n\r\n```\r\ndf %>% group_by(col1) %>% slice_sample(n = max(n() * 0.5,1))\r\n```\r\n\r\nreturns an error\r\n>Error: `n()` must only be used inside dplyr verbs.\r\n\r\nAm I missing something or this is a bug?",

#>     "closed_at": {},

#>     "active_lock_reason": {},
#>     "body": "I think this is a bug and not intended behaviour. Here's the reprex\r\n\r\n```r\r\ntibble(\r\n\tx = c(1,2)\r\n\t, y = c(3,4)\r\n\t, z = c(5,6)\r\n) %>% \r\n\tdplyr::group_by(y) %>%  #pre-existing grouping\r\n\tdplyr::group_by(across(any_of(c('y','z')))) %>% #tidyselect-specified grouping, \r\n\tdplyr::group_vars() \r\n```\r\nThis yields the value `\"z\"` instead of the expected `c(\"y\",\"z\")`. Simple solution is to always ungroup before grouping, but I thought you might want to be aware of this behaviour as it took me a while to work out that this was the culprit for some broken code.\r\n\r\n```\r\n> sessionInfo()\r\nR version 4.0.2 (2020-06-22)\r\nPlatform: x86_64-pc-linux-gnu (64-bit)\r\nRunning under: Ubuntu 20.04.1 LTS\r\n\r\nMatrix products: default\r\nBLAS:   /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/blas/libblas.so.3.9.0\r\nLAPACK: /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/lapack/liblapack.so.3.9.0\r\n\r\nlocale:\r\n [1] LC_CTYPE=en_CA.UTF-8       LC_NUMERIC=C              \r\n [3] LC_TIME=en_CA.UTF-8        LC_COLLATE=en_CA.UTF-8    \r\n [5] LC_MONETARY=en_CA.UTF-8    LC_MESSAGES=en_CA.UTF-8   \r\n [7] LC_PAPER=en_CA.UTF-8       LC_NAME=C                 \r\n [9] LC_ADDRESS=C               LC_TELEPHONE=C            \r\n[11] LC_MEASUREMENT=en_CA.UTF-8 LC_IDENTIFICATION=C       \r\n\r\nattached base packages:\r\n[1] stats     graphics  grDevices utils     datasets  methods   base     \r\n\r\nother attached packages:\r\n[1] forcats_0.5.0   stringr_1.4.0   dplyr_1.0.1     purrr_0.3.4     readr_1.3.1    \r\n[6] tidyr_1.1.1     tibble_3.0.3    ggplot2_3.3.2   tidyverse_1.3.0\r\n\r\nloaded via a namespace (and not attached):\r\n [1] Rcpp_1.0.5       cellranger_1.1.0 pillar_1.4.6     compiler_4.0.2  \r\n [5] dbplyr_1.4.4     tools_4.0.2      packrat_0.5.0    lubridate_1.7.9 \r\n [9] jsonlite_1.7.0   lifecycle_0.2.0  gtable_0.3.0     pkgconfig_2.0.3 \r\n[13] rlang_0.4.7      reprex_0.3.0     cli_2.0.2        DBI_1.1.0       \r\n[17] rstudioapi_0.11  haven_2.3.1      xfun_0.16        withr_2.2.0     \r\n[21] xml2_1.3.2       httr_1.4.2       fs_1.4.2         generics_0.0.2  \r\n[25] vctrs_0.3.2      hms_0.5.3        grid_4.0.2       tidyselect_1.1.0\r\n[29] glue_1.4.1       R6_2.4.1         fansi_0.4.1      readxl_1.3.1    \r\n[33] modelr_0.1.8     blob_1.2.1       magrittr_1.5     backports_1.1.8 \r\n[37] scales_1.1.1     ellipsis_0.3.1   rvest_0.3.6      assertthat_0.2.1\r\n[41] colorspace_1.4-1 tinytex_0.25     stringi_1.4.6    munsell_0.5.0   \r\n[45] broom_0.7.0      crayon_1.3.4    \r\n```",

#>     "number": 5455,
#>     "title": "Unexpected behavior using `group_by(.drop = FALSE)` with ordered factors",
#>     "user": {
#>       "login": "ddsjoberg",
#>       "id": 26774684,
#>       "node_id": "MDQ6VXNlcjI2Nzc0Njg0",

#>     "body": "When data is grouped with the argument `.drop = FALSE` and the grouping variable is an ordered factor, the `summarise()` function converts the ordered factor to an unordered factor in the resulting data frame. The same is true when using `count(..., .drop = FALSE)`. \r\n\r\nIs there some way to preserve the original class of the grouping variable, or is this an ordered factor bug? Thank you!\r\n\r\n``` r\r\nlibrary(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE)\r\n#> Warning: package 'dplyr' was built under R version 4.0.2\r\npackageVersion(\"dplyr\")\r\n#> [1] '1.0.1'\r\npackageVersion(\"vctrs\")\r\n#> [1] '0.3.2'\r\nmtcars %>%\r\n  as_tibble() %>%\r\n  mutate(cyl = factor(cyl, ordered = TRUE)) %>% # making cyl ordered factor\r\n  group_by(cyl, .drop = FALSE) %>%\r\n  summarize(n = n())\r\n#> `summarise()` ungrouping output (override with `.groups` argument)\r\n#> # A tibble: 3 x 2\r\n#>   cyl       n\r\n#>   <fct> <int>\r\n#> 1 4        11\r\n#> 2 6         7\r\n#> 3 8        14\r\n```\r\n\r\n<sup>Created on 2020-08-02 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)<\/sup>\r\n",

I have updated the description to highlight the fact that an `inner_join` only joins all rows from x and y **where there is a match in the key**.",

#>     "body": "This example on [colwise vignette](https://dplyr.tidyverse.org/articles/colwise.html) also calculates `max()` of `min()`ed values (`max_min_*`), which I don't think is intended. This made me think `across()` should have some option to distinguish the columns that is generated by `across()`. Is it technically possible...?\r\n\r\n``` r\r\nstarwars %>% summarise(\r\n  across(where(is.numeric), ~min(.x, na.rm = TRUE), .names = \"min_{col}\"),\r\n  across(where(is.numeric), ~max(.x, na.rm = TRUE), .names = \"max_{col}\")\r\n)\r\n#> # A tibble: 1 x 9\r\n#>   min_height min_mass min_birth_year max_height max_mass max_birth_year\r\n#>        <int>    <dbl>          <dbl>      <int>    <dbl>          <dbl>\r\n#> 1         66       15              8        264     1358            896\r\n#> # … with 3 more variables: max_min_height <int>, max_min_mass <dbl>,\r\n#> #   max_min_birth_year <dbl>\r\n```",

#>     ],
#>     "state": "open",
#>     "locked": false,
#>     "assignee": {},
#>     "assignees": [],
#>     "milestone": {},
#>     "comments": 3,
#>     "created_at": "2020-07-19T23:56:19Z",

#>     "closed_at": {},
#>     "author_association": "NONE",
#>     "active_lock_reason": {},
#>     "body": "Hi, \r\n\r\nIt would be great if join commands had the possibility to update values. \r\n\r\nFor example, I am working with data frame \"m\" and want to update the \"x\" values for some NA cases using another data frame \"y\".  Join commands will generate two columns x.x and x.y. Then, I would have to mutate values to update variables in this new, larger data.frame. \r\n\r\nHowever, if there was an update = T option, the new data.frame could automatically update NA values from the master data-set with the columns that have the same name in the using data set. Then, no new columns will be generated, I will be working in a smaller data-set and there would be no need to do any extra steps. \r\n\r\nThere could also be a conflict option to also manage the cases in which there are values in both the master and using data set. For example, if conflict = F, then when there are values in both master and using values then master data is retained, and nothing is changed in the column for rows that are present in master and using data. However, if conflict = T then the data from the using data set is retained. \r\n\r\nIn STATA this is part of the  [merge](https://www.stata.com/manuals13/dmerge.pdf) command. Some people have been asking the same and making some workarounds [example](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/51572462/update-replace-values-in-dataframe-with-tidyverse-join). \r\n \r\nThank you once again for dplyr.\r\n\r\n```r\r\nm <- data.frame(id  = c(1,2,3), x = c(4, 4, NA))\r\nu <- data.frame(id  = c(1,2,3), x = c(5, 5, 5))\r\n\r\n# Current results\r\nm %>% full_join(u, by = \"id\")\r\n\r\n# With update = T we want:\r\ndata.frame(id  = c(1,2,3), x  = c(4,4,5))\r\n\r\n# With update = T and conflict = T we want:\r\ndata.frame(id  = c(1,2,3), x  = c(5,5,5))\r\n# With update = T and conflict = F we want:\r\ndata.frame(id  = c(1,2,3), x  = c(4,4,5))\r\n\r\n\r\n```\r\n",

#>     "closed_at": {},
#>     "author_association": "NONE",
#>     "active_lock_reason": {},
#>     "body": "---\r\n\r\nHey! I know that row names on tibbles are deprecated (which I disagree with but that is beside the point) but I think that for now, given that someone wants to continue using this deprecated feature, functions like mutate should not drop rownames in cases by default where the user wants to keep them.  There are constructs outside of the tidyverse that still use rownames; for example the bioconductor object 'eset' uses them in important ways and there are tools that take esets and not more modern bioconductor objects.   So if I want to use tibbles and dplyr verbs when constructing esets I have to do inconvenient workarounds, or not use dplyr.   So what I want is for tidyverse functions to preserve rownames wherever possible, even though I know it is not possible with certain things (like joins where rows are added). \r\n\r\n\r\nHere is a simple example: \r\n```r\r\nlibrary(tidyverse)\r\nsmall_tibble <- mpg[1:3,1:3]\r\nrownames(small_tibble) <- c(\"snap\",\"cracke\",\"pop\")\r\nprint(rownames(small_tibble)) #setting rownames was successful\r\nsmall_tibble_mutated <- small_tibble %>% mutate(displ = displ^2)\r\nprint(rownames(small_tibble_mutated)) #rownames disappeared\r\n```\r\n",
#>     "performed_via_github_app": {}
#>   },

#>     "user": {
#>       "login": "Nico-Rojas",
#>       "id": 43378796,
#>       "node_id": "MDQ6VXNlcjQzMzc4Nzk2",

#>       "starred_url": "https://api.github.com/users/Nico-Rojas/starred{/owner}{/repo}",

#>       "type": "User",
#>       "site_admin": false
#>     },
#>     "labels": [
#>       {
#>         "id": 1257707950,
#>         "node_id": "MDU6TGFiZWwxMjU3NzA3OTUw",
#>         "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr/labels/join%20:twisted_rightwards_arrows:",
#>         "name": "join :twisted_rightwards_arrows:",
#>         "color": "eeeeee",
#>         "default": false,
#>         "description": "Related to joins"
#>       }
#>     ],
#>     "state": "open",
#>     "locked": false,
#>     "assignee": {},
#>     "assignees": [],
#>     "milestone": {},
#>     "comments": 0,
#>     "created_at": "2020-07-15T20:41:24Z",
#>     "updated_at": "2020-08-11T09:37:34Z",
#>     "closed_at": {},
#>     "author_association": "NONE",
#>     "active_lock_reason": {},
#>     "body": "It would be incredible if you could specify which kind of duplicates in the join variable(s) is(are) acceptable as in [the STATA merge command](https://www.stata.com/manuals13/dmerge.pdf). \r\n\r\nThis means having the possibility to decide whether it's ok to have: \r\n- Duplicates in the join variables of the master data but not in the join variables of the using data (a m:1 join)\r\n- Duplicates in the join variables of the using data but not in the join variables of the master data (a 1:m join)\r\n- Duplicates in both cases (an m:m join)\r\n- No duplicates (a 1:1 join)\r\n\r\nI work in education, and some times data-sets were poorly digitized because some students appear to have been enrolled in more than one school (duplicates in the join variable).  When that happens both in the master and using data, those students multiply exponentially in the resulting data-frame, as it happens now with, for example, left_join.  You may not want that. Also, if you are not cautious enough, you may not pay attention to duplicate students, that \"ninjaly\" add more observations to your results. \r\n\r\nSTATA used to have the same issue and only had two commands \"merge\" or \"join\" somehow similar to R, and did not let you decide when duplicates are acceptable (i.e duplicate information in the using data when merging students to school characteristics, school id is the join variable) and when it may not be acceptable (i.e duplicate information in the master and using data when merging a student list to a student characteristic, student id is the join variable). At some point, they made that feature feasible and it's great because it allows you to merge and make quality control in one single step. \r\n\r\nThank you for your time and amazing work. Hope this helps. \r\n",
#>     "performed_via_github_app": {}
#>   },
#>   {
#>     "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/5369",
#>     "repository_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr",

#>     "html_url": "https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/5369",
#>     "id": 647749307,
#>     "node_id": "MDU6SXNzdWU2NDc3NDkzMDc=",
#>     "number": 5369,
#>     "title": "Inconsistent and unpredictable behaviour from group_by with .drop=FALSE",
#>     "user": {
#>       "login": "pitakakariki",
#>       "id": 1023705,
#>       "node_id": "MDQ6VXNlcjEwMjM3MDU=",
#>       "avatar_url": "https://avatars0.githubusercontent.com/u/1023705?v=4",
#>       "gravatar_id": "",
#>       "url": "https://api.github.com/users/pitakakariki",
#>       "html_url": "https://github.com/pitakakariki",
#>       "followers_url": "https://api.github.com/users/pitakakariki/followers",
#>       "following_url": "https://api.github.com/users/pitakakariki/following{/other_user}",
#>       "gists_url": "https://api.github.com/users/pitakakariki/gists{/gist_id}",
#>       "starred_url": "https://api.github.com/users/pitakakariki/starred{/owner}{/repo}",
#>       "subscriptions_url": "https://api.github.com/users/pitakakariki/subscriptions",
#>       "organizations_url": "https://api.github.com/users/pitakakariki/orgs",
#>       "repos_url": "https://api.github.com/users/pitakakariki/repos",
#>       "events_url": "https://api.github.com/users/pitakakariki/events{/privacy}",
#>       "received_events_url": "https://api.github.com/users/pitakakariki/received_events",
#>       "type": "User",
#>       "site_admin": false
#>     },
#>     "labels": [],
#>     "state": "open",
#>     "locked": false,
#>     "assignee": {},
#>     "assignees": [],
#>     "milestone": {},
#>     "comments": 7,
#>     "created_at": "2020-06-30T00:10:09Z",
#>     "updated_at": "2020-08-31T13:04:32Z",
#>     "closed_at": {},
#>     "author_association": "NONE",
#>     "active_lock_reason": {},
#>     "body": "The effect of the `.drop=FALSE` argument to `group_by` depends on whether the grouping variables are explicitly factors or not.\r\n\r\n``` r\r\nlibrary(dplyr, warn.conflicts=FALSE)\r\n\r\nmtcars %>%\r\n  \r\n  group_by(gear, am, .drop=FALSE) %>%\r\n  \r\n  summarise(count=n(), .groups=\"drop\")\r\n#> # A tibble: 4 x 3\r\n#>    gear    am count\r\n#>   <dbl> <dbl> <int>\r\n#> 1     3     0    15\r\n#> 2     4     0     4\r\n#> 3     4     1     8\r\n#> 4     5     1     5\r\n\r\nmtcars %>%\r\n  \r\n  mutate(am=as.factor(am)) %>%\r\n  \r\n  group_by(gear, am, .drop=FALSE) %>%\r\n  \r\n  summarise(count=n(), .groups=\"drop\")\r\n#> # A tibble: 6 x 3\r\n#>    gear am    count\r\n#>   <dbl> <fct> <int>\r\n#> 1     3 0        15\r\n#> 2     3 1         0\r\n#> 3     4 0         4\r\n#> 4     4 1         8\r\n#> 5     5 0         0\r\n#> 6     5 1         5\r\n```\r\n\r\n<sup>Created on 2020-06-30 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)<\/sup>\r\n\r\nSince all grouping variables are either explicitly or impicitly factors, I would expect similar behaviour in each case (unless there are additional values encoded in `levels` but not seen in the data, which is not the case here).\r\n\r\nSome combinations of implicit and explicit factors give very strange results (note that there are no `NA`'s in `mtcars`):\r\n\r\n``` r\r\nlibrary(dplyr, warn.conflicts=FALSE)\r\n\r\nmtcars %>%\r\n  \r\n  mutate(am=as.factor(am)) %>%\r\n  \r\n  group_by(gear, am, cyl, .drop=FALSE) %>%\r\n  \r\n  summarise(count=n(), .groups=\"drop\")\r\n#> # A tibble: 12 x 4\r\n#>     gear am      cyl count\r\n#>    <dbl> <fct> <dbl> <int>\r\n#>  1     3 0         4     1\r\n#>  2     3 0         6     2\r\n#>  3     3 0         8    12\r\n#>  4     3 1        NA     0\r\n#>  5     4 0         4     2\r\n#>  6     4 0         6     2\r\n#>  7     4 1         4     6\r\n#>  8     4 1         6     2\r\n#>  9     5 0        NA     0\r\n#> 10     5 1         4     2\r\n#> 11     5 1         6     1\r\n#> 12     5 1         8     2\r\n```\r\n\r\n<sup>Created on 2020-06-30 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)<\/sup>\r\n\r\nTo be absolutely clear, you can recover the intended and expected behaviour in these cases by converting all of the grouping variables to explicit factors:\r\n\r\n``` r\r\nlibrary(dplyr, warn.conflicts=FALSE)\r\n\r\nmtcars %>%\r\n  \r\n  mutate(gear=as.factor(gear), am=as.factor(am)) %>%\r\n  \r\n  group_by(gear, am, .drop=FALSE) %>%\r\n  \r\n  summarise(count=n(), .groups=\"drop\")\r\n#> # A tibble: 6 x 3\r\n#>   gear  am    count\r\n#>   <fct> <fct> <int>\r\n#> 1 3     0        15\r\n#> 2 3     1         0\r\n#> 3 4     0         4\r\n#> 4 4     1         8\r\n#> 5 5     0         0\r\n#> 6 5     1         5\r\n\r\nmtcars %>%\r\n  \r\n  mutate(gear=as.factor(gear), am=as.factor(am), cyl=as.factor(cyl)) %>%\r\n  \r\n  group_by(gear, am, cyl, .drop=FALSE) %>%\r\n  \r\n  summarise(count=n(), .groups=\"drop\")\r\n#> # A tibble: 18 x 4\r\n#>    gear  am    cyl   count\r\n#>    <fct> <fct> <fct> <int>\r\n#>  1 3     0     4         1\r\n#>  2 3     0     6         2\r\n#>  3 3     0     8        12\r\n#>  4 3     1     4         0\r\n#>  5 3     1     6         0\r\n#>  6 3     1     8         0\r\n#>  7 4     0     4         2\r\n#>  8 4     0     6         2\r\n#>  9 4     0     8         0\r\n#> 10 4     1     4         6\r\n#> 11 4     1     6         2\r\n#> 12 4     1     8         0\r\n#> 13 5     0     4         0\r\n#> 14 5     0     6         0\r\n#> 15 5     0     8         0\r\n#> 16 5     1     4         2\r\n#> 17 5     1     6         1\r\n#> 18 5     1     8         2\r\n```\r\n\r\n<sup>Created on 2020-06-30 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)<\/sup>\r\n",

#>       {
#>         "id": 17708200,
#>         "node_id": "MDU6TGFiZWwxNzcwODIwMA==",
#>         "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr/labels/feature",

#>       {
#>         "id": 334471510,
#>         "node_id": "MDU6TGFiZWwzMzQ0NzE1MTA=",
#>         "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/tidyverse/dplyr/labels/verbs%20:running_woman:",
#>         "name": "verbs :running_woman:",
#>         "color": "eeeeee",
#>         "default": false,
#>         "description": ""
#>       }
#>     ],
#>     "state": "open",
#>     "locked": false,
#>     "assignee": {},
#>     "assignees": [],
#>     "milestone": {},
#>     "comments": 4,
#>     "created_at": "2020-06-04T12:34:44Z",
#>     "updated_at": "2020-07-01T11:16:27Z",
#>     "closed_at": {},
#>     "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
#>     "active_lock_reason": {},
#>     "body": "A really useful feature of `sample_n()` is the ability to vary `size` by the grouping variable(s):\r\n\r\n```r\r\nlibrary(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE)\r\npackageVersion(\"dplyr\")\r\n#> [1] '1.0.0'\r\n\r\nset.seed(123223)\r\n\r\nstarwars %>%\r\n  select(name, sex, homeworld) %>%\r\n  add_count(sex, homeworld, name = \"number\") %>%\r\n  group_by(sex, homeworld) %>%\r\n  sample_n(size = case_when(\r\n    number %in% 1:4 ~ 1,\r\n    number >= 5 ~ 2\r\n  )) %>%\r\n  ungroup() %>%\r\n  arrange(desc(number), homeworld)\r\n#> # A tibble: 64 x 4\r\n#>    name                sex    homeworld number\r\n#>    <chr>               <chr>  <chr>      <int>\r\n#>  1 Owen Lars           male   Tatooine       6\r\n#>  2 Darth Vader         male   Tatooine       6\r\n#>  3 Jar Jar Binks       male   Naboo          5\r\n#>  4 Rugor Nass          male   Naboo          5\r\n#>  5 Finn                male   <NA>           5\r\n#>  6 Yoda                male   <NA>           5\r\n#>  7 Dormé               female Naboo          3\r\n#>  8 BB8                 none   <NA>           3\r\n#>  9 Bail Prestor Organa male   Alderaan       2\r\n#> 10 Wedge Antilles      male   Corellia       2\r\n#> # … with 54 more rows\r\n```\r\n\r\nSwitching to `sample_n()`'s successor `slice_sample()` yields a different number of rows:\r\n\r\n```r\r\nlibrary(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE)\r\npackageVersion(\"dplyr\")\r\n#> [1] '1.0.0'\r\n\r\nset.seed(123223)\r\n\r\nstarwars %>%\r\n  select(name, sex, homeworld) %>%\r\n  add_count(sex, homeworld, name = \"number\") %>%\r\n  group_by(sex, homeworld) %>%\r\n  slice_sample(n = case_when(\r\n    \"number\" %in% 1:4 ~ 1,\r\n    \"number\" >= 5 ~ 2\r\n  )) %>%\r\n  ungroup() %>%\r\n  arrange(desc(number), homeworld)\r\n#> # A tibble: 75 x 4\r\n#>    name              sex    homeworld number\r\n#>    <chr>             <chr>  <chr>      <int>\r\n#>  1 Cliegg Lars       male   Tatooine       6\r\n#>  2 Biggs Darklighter male   Tatooine       6\r\n#>  3 Palpatine         male   Naboo          5\r\n#>  4 Rugor Nass        male   Naboo          5\r\n#>  5 Qui-Gon Jinn      male   <NA>           5\r\n#>  6 Finn              male   <NA>           5\r\n#>  7 Dormé             female Naboo          3\r\n#>  8 Padmé Amidala     female Naboo          3\r\n#>  9 R4-P17            none   <NA>           3\r\n#> 10 BB8               none   <NA>           3\r\n#> # … with 65 more rows\r\n```\r\n\r\n`sample_n()` is behaving as I would expect: returning one sample per combination of `sex` and `homeworld` when said combination occurs between 1 and 4 times; and two samples per combination when there are 5 or more occurrences.\r\n\r\nMaybe I'm doing something wrong, but `slice_sample()` is returning two samples for all combinations of `sex` and `homeworld`, regardless of the number of times said combination occurs, except for combinations which only occur once, which can only return one sample.",
#>     "performed_via_github_app": {}
#>   },

#>     "milestone": {

#>     "body": "According to the documentation, `select()` should preserve attributes (\"Data frame attributes are preserved.\" in section Value). However, this seems to work only for tibbles, not for data frames. This is an reproducible example:\r\n\r\n```\r\nmtcars_df <- mtcars\r\nattr(mtcars_df, \"test\") <- TRUE\r\nmtcars_tib <- as_tibble(mtcars_df)\r\nattr(mtcars_df, \"test\")\r\nattr(mtcars_tib, \"test\")\r\n\r\nattr(dplyr::select(mtcars_df), \"test\")\r\nattr(dplyr::select(mtcars_tib), \"test\")\r\n```\r\n\r\nWith dplyr 0.8.5, all the four calls of `attr()` return `TRUE` as expected. But with dplyr 1.0.0, `attr(dplyr::select(mtcars_df), \"test\")` returns `NULL`.\r\n\r\nThe result does not change, if some columns are selected.",

#>     "body": "I am having a perf issue with across.\r\n\r\n2s versus 74s depending on the writing.\r\n\r\nMy dplyr version: 0.8.99.9003\r\n```r\r\nmun2014 <- vroom(\"https://data.regardscitoyens.org/elections/2014_municipales/MN14_Bvot_T1_01-49.txt\", \r\n                 col_select = -c('X4','X9','X10','X11'),\r\n                 col_names = FALSE, \r\n                 locale = locale(encoding = \"WINDOWS-1252\")) \r\n# 275000 obs, 9 variables\r\n\r\nsystem.time( dataag1 <- mun2014 %>%\r\n               group_by_if( is.character )  %>%\r\n               summarise_if( is_numeric, sum ) \r\n)\r\n# 1.4s\r\n\r\nsystem.time( dataag2 <- mun2014 %>%\r\n              group_by( across(where(is.character)) )  %>%\r\n              summarise( across(where(is_numeric), sum) ) \r\n)\r\n# 74 s\r\n\r\nall.equal(dataag1,dataag2)\r\n# true\r\n\r\n# by the way: is there a simplier manner to use across here?\r\n```\r\n",

#>     "body": "``` r\r\nlibrary(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE)\r\n\r\ndf <- tibble(a = 1:4)\r\n\r\nslice(df, 1)\r\n#> # A tibble: 1 x 1\r\n#>       a\r\n#>   <int>\r\n#> 1     1\r\nslice(df, -1)\r\n#> # A tibble: 3 x 1\r\n#>       a\r\n#>   <int>\r\n#> 1     2\r\n#> 2     3\r\n#> 3     4\r\n\r\nslice(df, 5)\r\n#> Error: Can't subset elements that don't exist.\r\n#> x Location 5 doesn't exist.\r\n#> ℹ There are only 4 elements.\r\nslice(df, NA)\r\n#> # A tibble: 1 x 1\r\n#>       a\r\n#>   <int>\r\n#> 1    NA\r\nslice(df, c(NA, 1))\r\n#> # A tibble: 2 x 1\r\n#>       a\r\n#>   <int>\r\n#> 1    NA\r\n#> 2     1\r\n```\r\n\r\n<sup>Created on 2020-05-22 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)<\/sup>\r\n\r\nI guess this would need some way to forgive about out of bounds, and also disregard missing values. Same reprex on master: \r\n\r\n``` r\r\nlibrary(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE)\r\n\r\ndf <- tibble(a = 1:4)\r\n\r\nslice(df, 1)\r\n#> # A tibble: 1 x 1\r\n#>       a\r\n#>   <int>\r\n#> 1     1\r\nslice(df, -1)\r\n#> # A tibble: 3 x 1\r\n#>       a\r\n#>   <int>\r\n#> 1     2\r\n#> 2     3\r\n#> 3     4\r\n\r\nslice(df, 5)\r\n#> # A tibble: 0 x 1\r\n#> # … with 1 variable: a <int>\r\nslice(df, NA)\r\n#> # A tibble: 0 x 1\r\n#> # … with 1 variable: a <int>\r\nslice(df, c(NA, 1))\r\n#> # A tibble: 1 x 1\r\n#>       a\r\n#>   <int>\r\n#> 1     1\r\n```\r\n\r\n<sup>Created on 2020-05-22 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)<\/sup>\r\n\r\nI guess if we were to maintain current `slice()` choices, we would need: \r\n\r\n`num_as_location(missing = \"drop\", oob = \"drop\")` or something similar. @lionel- \r\n",

#>     "closed_at": {},
#>     "author_association": "NONE",
#>     "active_lock_reason": {},
#>     "body": "A one-line reprex of this behavior is:\r\n\r\n``` r\r\ndplyr::rename(data.frame(old = 1), new = c(dud = \"old\"))\r\n#>   new...dud\r\n#> 1         1\r\n```\r\n\r\nThis is an issue if we have a function where data.frames with myriad names have their names changed to certain \"standard\" names. In the case below, I have a standard column-name `foo`, but a data.frame's called it `bar` instead, so we call the following function to give it the standard name\r\n\r\n``` r\r\nstandardize <- function(df, fooName) {\r\n  dplyr::rename(df, foo = !!fooName)\r\n}\r\n\r\nstandardize(data.frame(bar = 1), \"bar\")\r\n#>   foo\r\n#> 1   1\r\n```\r\n\r\n<sup>Created on 2020-05-07 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)<\/sup>\r\n\r\nThis works just fine.\r\n\r\nHowever, if, for whatever reason, the value passed to `fooName` is a length-1 named vector, we get the behavior shown at the start:\r\n\r\n``` r\r\nname <- c(buzz = \"bar\")\r\nstandardize(data.frame(bar = 1), name)\r\n#>   foo...buzz\r\n#> 1          1\r\n```\r\n\r\nThe vector's name is clumsily suffixed to the desired name with an ellipsis. Is this expected behavior? I'm currently solving this by using `foo = unname(fooName)`, which works, but wonder if this is just a bug.",
#>     "performed_via_github_app": {}
#>   },

#>     "closed_at": {},
#>     "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
#>     "active_lock_reason": {},
#>     "body": "This has been discussed in various issues and forums, notably:\r\n\r\n- https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/237, suggesting `group_by_adj()` (suggesting pre-ordered adjacency);\r\n- https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/1534;\r\n- https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/1661; and\r\n- https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/4445 (most recent)\r\n\r\nOne key difference is that some of those discussions focused on a new `group_by_*` verb, where I suggest having just a helper function is sufficient to scratch the itch sufficiently. Lacking safeguards and sanity checks, it could be as straight-forward as:\r\n\r\n```r\r\nrle_group <- function(...) {\r\n  yy <- rle(paste(...))\r\n  rep(seq_along(yy$lengths), yy$lengths)\r\n}\r\n\r\ndf <- data.frame(x = c(0, 0, 1, 0), y = c(2, 2, 2, 2))\r\ndf %>%\r\n  group_by(grp = rle_group(x, y))\r\n# # A tibble: 4 x 3\r\n# # Groups:   grp [3]\r\n#       x     y   grp\r\n#   <dbl> <dbl> <int>\r\n# 1     0     2     1\r\n# 2     0     2     1\r\n# 3     1     2     2\r\n# 4     0     2     3\r\n```\r\n\r\nThe under-inspiring `Groups: grp` may not be as informative as [Romain's previous suggestion](https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/237#issuecomment-35085223) of\r\n\r\n```lang-r\r\n> df <- data.frame( x = 1, a = rep(c(1,2), each = 4), b = rep( letters[1:2], each = 2), stringsAsFactors = TRUE )\r\n> gdf <- grouped_df_adj_impl( df, list( quote(x), quote(a), quote(b) ), FALSE )\r\n> summarise(gdf, n = n() )\r\nSource: local data frame [4 x 4]\r\nGroups: x, a\r\n\r\n  x a b n\r\n1 1 1 a 2\r\n2 1 1 b 2\r\n3 1 2 a 2\r\n4 1 2 b 2\r\n```\r\n\r\n(where the `Groups: x, a` is more useful), it still enables the grouping.\r\n\r\nThis comes up frequently enough on StackOverflow that I think its utility is justified. I think the implementation could be innocuous enough to not impact other verbs.\r\n\r\nThe use of `paste` enables \"one or more\" columns, and happens to side-step `rle`'s avoidance of `factor`. It does add overhead, so a more performant variant might be supported (that does not omit `factor`s). I'd think a variant of [Hadley's initial suggestion](https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/237#issuecomment-34117419) (Rcpp-based) could be adapted to handle one-or-more.\r\n\r\nI'd be willing to start on a PR if maintainers support the concept.",
