#>     "closed_at": {},
#>     "author_association": "NONE",
#>     "active_lock_reason": {},
#>     "body": "\r\nRunning a `summarise()` across a difftime variable on a grouped dataset has exceptionally poor performance. This is noticeable in that the poor performance doesn't occur in base R or data.table and also doesn't occur in dplyr if you cast the variable to numeric. \r\n\r\nRe-producible example below (using dplyr 0.8.5)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n```r\r\nn <- 2000000\r\nlibrary(dplyr)\r\nlibrary(data.table)\r\n\r\na = as.Date('2018-01-01')\r\nb = as.Date('2019-01-01')\r\n\r\ndat_num <- tibble(\r\n    patientid = sample( 1:50000, replace = TRUE, size = n ),\r\n    value = difftime(b, a, unit = \"days\")  %>% as.numeric()\r\n)\r\n\r\ndat_date <- tibble(\r\n    patientid = sample( 1:50000, replace = TRUE, size = n ),\r\n    value = difftime(b, a, unit = \"days\") \r\n)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n### Dplyr - numeric (quick)\r\nsystem.time({\r\n    dat_num %>%\r\n        group_by(patientid) %>%\r\n        summarise( m = max(value))\r\n})\r\n\r\n### Dplyr - difftime (takes forever to run) \r\nsystem.time({\r\n    dat_date %>%\r\n        group_by(patientid) %>%\r\n        summarise( m = max(value))\r\n})\r\n\r\n\r\n### Base R - numeric (quick)\r\nsystem.time({\r\n    tapply( X = dat_num$value, dat_num$patientid, max)\r\n})\r\n\r\n### Base R - difftime (quick)\r\nsystem.time({\r\n    tapply( X = dat_date$value, dat_date$patientid, max)\r\n})\r\n\r\n\r\n### data.table - numeric (quick)\r\nsystem.time({\r\n    x <- as.data.table(dat_num)\r\n    x[, .(m = max(value)), by = patientid]\r\n})\r\n\r\n### data.table - difftime (quick)\r\nsystem.time({\r\n    x <- as.data.table(dat_date)\r\n    x[, .(m = max(value)), by = patientid]\r\n})\r\n\r\n```\r\n\r\n\r\n```\r\nplatform       x86_64-apple-darwin15.6.0   \r\narch           x86_64                      \r\nos             darwin15.6.0                \r\nsystem         x86_64, darwin15.6.0        \r\nstatus                                     \r\nmajor          3                           \r\nminor          6.3                         \r\nyear           2020                        \r\nmonth          02                          \r\nday            29                          \r\nsvn rev        77875                       \r\nlanguage       R                           \r\nversion.string R version 3.6.3 (2020-02-29)\r\nnickname       Holding the Windsock \r\n```\r\n\r\n",
#>     "performed_via_github_app": {}
#>   }
#> ] 
#> > users <- gh("/users", .limit = 50)
#> > length(users)
#> [1] 50
if (FALSE) (if (getRversion() >= "3.4") withAutoprint else force)({ # examplesIf
## Access developer preview of Licenses API (in preview as of 2015-09-24)
gh("/licenses") # used to error code 415
gh("/licenses", .accept = "application/vnd.github.drax-preview+json")
}) # examplesIf
if (FALSE) (if (getRversion() >= "3.4") withAutoprint else force)({ # examplesIf
## Access Github Enterprise API
## Use GITHUB_API_URL environment variable to change the default.
gh("/user/repos", type = "public", .api_url = "https://github.foobar.edu/api/v3")
}) # examplesIf
if (FALSE) (if (getRversion() >= "3.4") withAutoprint else force)({ # examplesIf
## Use I() to force body part to be sent as an array, even if length 1
## This works whether assignees has length 1 or > 1
assignees <- "gh_user"
assignees <- c("gh_user1", "gh_user2")
gh("PATCH /repos/OWNER/REPO/issues/1", assignees = I(assignees))
}) # examplesIf
if (FALSE) (if (getRversion() >= "3.4") withAutoprint else force)({ # examplesIf
## There are two ways to send JSON data. One is that you supply one or
## more objects that will be converted to JSON automatically via
## jsonlite::toJSON(). In this case sometimes you need to use
## jsonlite::unbox() because fromJSON() creates lists from scalar vectors
## by default. The Content-Type header is automatically added in this
## case. For example this request turns on GitHub Pages, using this
## API: https://docs.github.com/v3/repos/pages/#enable-a-pages-site

gh::gh(
  "POST /repos/{owner}/{repo}/pages",
  owner = "gaborcsardi",
  repo = "playground",
  source = list(
    branch = jsonlite::unbox("master"),
    path = jsonlite::unbox("/docs")
  ),
  .send_headers = c(Accept = "application/vnd.github.switcheroo-preview+json")
)

## The second way is to handle the JSON encoding manually, and supply it
## as a raw vector in an unnamed argument, and also a Content-Type header:

body <- '{ "source": { "branch": "master", "path": "/docs" } }'
gh::gh(
  "POST /repos/{owner}/{repo}/pages",
  owner = "gaborcsardi",
  repo = "playground",
  charToRaw(body),
  .send_headers = c(
    Accept = "application/vnd.github.switcheroo-preview+json",
    "Content-Type" = "application/json"
  )
)
}) # examplesIf

Contents

Developed by Gábor Csárdi, Jennifer Bryan, Hadley Wickham, .

Site built with pkgdown 1.5.1.
